On  0, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...> wrote:
 
> >  Now about "too big" part. I'm not sure if you can do anything with
> use 
> >  case size itself. You can implement scenarios one-by-one, in order
> you 
> >  suggested, and make each flow a separate story. But all of them 
> >  still belong to the same use case! From this point of view, it is
> right 
> >  to have Customer test per scenario.
> 
> I agree that some use cases are just big, although they may be able to
> be decomposed into smaller use cases, depending on the details.
> 
> Again, depending on how one defines "scenario", one may need to write
> many Customer Tests for one scenario, especially if different input
> data materially affects the flow. (One could argue that this creates a
> distinct scenario, and I generally agree, but I have to allow for the
> fact that different people use the same terms differently.)

  You're right, it depends on the definition of the scenario. 
  From my point of view, if scenario flow depends on input data, 
  we have several scenarios (one per input data set). Not sure, how 
  it is defined in Big methodologies like RUP.

> <snip />
>
> In short, Programmer Test names reflect the design; Customer Test names
> reflect the domain.

  I'm completely agree with this statement. 

> <snip />
>
> >
> >  Thank you for the offer. BTW, is is OK to post draft on the list
> >  for feedback? Possibly someone else will also want to comment.
> 
> I don't mind if they don't mind.
> 
> Have fun with it. I have my own writing to do. :)

   Good luck :). 

   KIR
